Taylor expansion of ln (1+x) is:1-> ln (1+x) = x - x^2/2 + x^3/3 - x^4/4 + x^5/5 -+-Putting x = 1.2-> ln (1 + 1) = ln (2) = 1 - 1/2 + 1/3 - 1/4 + 1/5 -+-Rearranging the terms3-> ln (2) = (1 + 1/3 + 1/5 +++) - (1/2 + 1/4 + 1/6 +++)4-> Let P = 1 + 1/3 + 1/5 +++5-> Let Q = 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/6 +++From steps 3, 4 and 56-> ln (2) = P - QConsider Q7-> Q = 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/6 + 1/8 + 1/10 +++Taking 1/2 as common from LHS.8-> Q = 1/2 [1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/4 + 1/5 +++]Rearranging terms9-> Q = 1/2 [ (1 + 1/3 + 1/5 +++) + (1/2 + 1/4 + 1/6 +++) ]Subsituting series in step 9 with help of step 4 and 5,10-> Q = 1/2 [ P + Q]11-> 2Q = P + Q12-> Q = PSubstituting Q in step 6.13-> ln (2) = P - P14-> ln (2) = 0Taking antilogs on both sides15-> 2 = 1Best of Luck to my esteemed opponent.
